sectionTitle: Future and Present Values of Multiple Cash Flows

columns.text: In this exercise, we will discuss the calculation of the present and the future value of a series of cash flows and the factors to consider.

A. For the first requirement, we will discuss how to calculate the future value of a series of cash flows.

There is two way in calculating the future value of a cash flow series, which are the following:

- First is by compounding the accumulated cash flows balance forward for each period considering the future value interest rate.

- Another alternative is independently calculating the cash flow for each period and combining all the values on the last year to determine the net future value of the cash flows.

B. For the following requirement, we will explain how to compute the present value of a series of cash flows.

Similar to calculating the future value, there is also two way of calculating the present value of a series of cash flows which are as follows:

- First is by dividing each period's cash flows over their respective discount rate.

- Second is by separately calculating the present value of each period and combining all the values at the end of the year.

C. For the last requirement, discuss what cash flow timing we usually consider unless explicitly told otherwise.

The cash flow timing is a vital factor in calculating the present or future value of a cash flow. In cash flows computations, it is always assumed that the cash flow occurs at the end of the year unless otherwise stated.
This task requires us to discuss the calculations of present/future annuity values.

Before we proceed, let's recall how present and future value of singular flow/asset.

**Present value of single cash flow** is calculated as:

$$\text{PV}_\text{s}=\text{C} \times \frac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}$$

where:

$\text{C}$ = deposit amount;\
$\text{r}$ =  interest rate;\
$\text{t}$ = amount of periods passed.

**Future value of single cash flow** is calculated as:

$$\text{FV}_\text{s}=\text{C} \times(1+\text{r})^\text{t}$$

where all the parameters that were used are the same parameters used in present value formula.

## Requirement 1

Firstly, we need to discuss how the future value can be calculated.


Future value can be calculated in two ways.

1. Compounding one period at the time.

Starting from the beginning, we are calculating  **how the future value of increases with consecutive deposits, ie. between same time period** and then adding up standard deposit value at each period.

For example, we will have 3 1-year-periods, each with $2,000 deposited each year, and interest rate of 20% (demonstrative numbers). We will need future value after 3 years.

With this method, we start at beginning, year 0. There is no deposit and no money in this period, therefore the amount is $\text{C}_0=\$0$ and consequently future value is $\text{FV}_{0}=\$0$.

In first year, we have our first deposit. As there is no future value between 0th and 1st years, only amount in first year we have is the deposited amount, ie. $\text{C}_1=\$2,000$.

Now, in second year, we have standard yearly deposit, however, **we now also have future value of the money deposited in previous year** ie. year 1 in this case.

The future value of year 1 money is as follows as only 1 year passed ($\text{t}=1$):

$$\begin{aligned}\text{FV}_1&=\text{C}_1 \times(1+\text{r})^\text{t}
\\[10pt]
&=\$2,000 \times (1+0.2)^1\\[10pt]
&=\$2,400\end{aligned}$$

With the standard yearly deposit, at the end of the second year we will have:

$$\text{C}_2=\$2,400+\$2,000=\$4,400$$

Similarly, in third year, we will need the future value of the amount in second year (between second and third year, period is also one year, ie. $\text{t}=1$):

$$\text{FV}_2=\$4,400 \times (1+0.2)^1=\$5,280$$

With standard yearly deposit, final value after three years would be:

$$\text{C}_3=\$5,280+\$2,000=\$7,280$$

As we can see, we have been just continually increasing the amount one period at the time, and on top of adding in standard deposit values, we've reached the total future value by compounding the values.

This result should be the same as a result used in the other method. Let's check that now.

2. Calculating each cash flow separately.

In contrast to the previous method, here we don't stack up all flows together together, here **we look at each cash flow separately and how much each flow contributes, depending on its deposit time**.

As we have established, we are working within a three-year period. 

This means that deposit in **first year** has **two years** to accumulate value, deposit in *second year has* *one year* to accumulate value and deposit in third year has no time, ie. it's value is just the deposit amount. 

|Year|C| $\times$| $(1+\text{r})^\text{t}$|=|FV|
|:--:|:--:|:--:|:--:|:--:|:--:|
|1|\$2,000| $\times$| $(1+0.2)^2$|=|\$2,880|
|2|\$2,000 |$\times$ |$(1+0.2)^1$|=|\$2,400|
|3|\$2,000| $\times$| $(1+0.2)^0$|=|\$2,000|

From the table, we can determine the total future value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}_\text{t}&=\text{PV}_1+\text{PV}_2+\text{PV}_3\\[10pt]
&=\$2,880 +\$2,400 + \$2,000\\[10pt]
&=\$7,280
\end{aligned}$$

As we see, the total amount matches with the amount in the first method.

## Requirement 2

Next, we have to look at how present value of multiple cash flows is calculated.

Present value is also calculated in same two ways as future, with some differences:

1. Compounding one period at the time.

Contrary to the future, we are now looking **backwards**, we are calculating  **how the present value decreases with consecutive deposits, ie. between same time period**. The standard yearly deposit is still added at each period.

Same example, we will have 3 1-year-periods, each with $2000 deposited each year, and interest rate of 20% . We will need present value of 3 years.

We are starting at the end now, ie. third year. There is only standard deposit but no present value from the year after that (there is no year 4), ie. $\text{C}_3=\$2000$ and $\text{PV}_0$=0$.

At second year, there is a standard yearly deposit. However, **the present value of the amount of third year now decreases**. 

Present value of the third-year amount is (as period is between 2nd and 1st year, period is $\text{t}=1$):

$$\text{PV}_3=\$2000 \times \frac{1}{(1+0.2)^1}=\$1666.7$$

With the deposit amount, the value at second year is:

$$\text{C}_2=\$2,000+\$1,666.7=\$3,666.7$$

At first year, there is a standard yearly deposit added on the present value of the second-year amount. (as period is between 2nd and 1st year, period is $t=1$):


Present value of the amount in second year is:

$$\text{PV}_2=\$3,666.7 \times \frac{1}{(1+0.2)^1}=\$3,055.6$$

With the deposit amount, the total amount in first year is:

$$\text{C}_1=\$2,000+\$3,055.6=\$5,055.6$$

As there is no deposit in the beginning, total present value will be present value of year 1 amount:

$$\text{PV}_\text{t}=5,055.6 \times \frac{1}{(1+0.2)^1}=\$4,213$$

As we can see, we started with the amount in the future and we calculated its value by decreasing its value one period at the time (on top of adding in the deposit amount every period), ie. compounded discounting.

We can also expect that the other method will give us the same result.

2. Discounting each flow separately

Same as with future value, we are observing **reduction in value of each cash flow, depending on its deposit time**.

Since we are working with a period of three years, deposit at **third year** has **three years** to 'lose' value, deposit at *second year* has *two years* and deposit at first year has one year.


|Year|C| $\times$| $\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^\text{t}}$|=|PV|
|:--:|:--:|:--:|:--:|:--:|:--:|
|3|\$2,000| $\times$| $\dfrac{1}{(1+0.2)^3}$|=|\$1,157.4|
|2|\$2,000 |$\times$ |$\dfrac{1}{(1+0.2)^2}$|=|\$1,388.9|
|1|\$2,000| $\times$| $\dfrac{1}{(1+0.2)}$|=|\$1,666.7|

Adding all the present values calculated in the previous step, we have the total present value of:


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PV}_\text{t}&=1,157.4+1,388.9+1,666.7\\[10pt]
&=\$4,213
\end{aligned}$$

Again, the values are the same, as expected.

## Requirement 3

Finally we need to determine what is presumed about timing regardless of which method is used for calculating either value.

All calculations are done under presumption that **payment always occurs at the end of the period**. This always true, and is explicitly stated if it's otherwise.
